Posts.Title: sick on the first day? rabbit rabbit

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2011 05:37AM rabbit wrote: hi Lena I was already on ativan for mild panic attacks in the past, but really only took one or two a month...glad I have the script now, I had them give me some ativan during my chemo, it helped me stay calm, I think I'll ask for it each time! I have a script of phenergan and I had zofran left over from ages ago.... it seems the zofran works best, but I've only had a touch of nausea, not too bad, so when I take a zofran it seems to never get worse.  I've been doing baking soda mouth washes 3-4x a day, I'm hoping to avoid that nasty thrush I keep hearing about, anyone have any other good preventatives for that?   Kim, I'm glad you are doing well, I have made a list of things to tell the assistants and Dr. Hargis when I see him Wed. I'm sure he'll help out, I think I've been pretty lucky over all.  Kim, did or do you have a port? When does that get out? I can't wait for that day LOL
Posts.Title: sick on the first day? rabbit rabbit

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2011 06:19PM rabbit wrote: I guess FEC is pretty common for a grade 3 IDC? It seems that's what we have in common....I do the taxotere after the 4 rounds of FEC. It's good to know others are on the same.  Trisha-Anne, funny you mentioned cheese, it's one of the few things that actually taste good to me, I had a spinach quesadilla today, was craving it bad, chicken and veggies for dinner last night, not bad, but cheese just seems to taste great, not much else does! I cut my hair from waist lenght a month ago, to shoulder length, which you can see in the pic, I'm on the right, my sister on the left. And just a week ago, got a pixie cut, I used that pic from my first chemo with my hair cut before but decided to change it. I guess I'll shave my head in a week or less.

I survived, my hair is starting to grow back and I even noticed eyelashes coming in today.  If anyone wants to ask questions, please feel free to :) This forum is incredible and has helped me in so many ways. Hugs to you all!!!

Posts.Title: sick on the first day? rabbit rabbit

Posts.Content: rabbit wrote: Just curious how many of you started with the nausea and felt like a truck ran over you, hours after chemo?  I didn't expect it at all...was home around 3 and by 5:30 or so I started with the nausea, then headaches and then very flu like symptoms, no fever.. I have not heard of anyone else doing this here...anyone? I hope this doesn't mean I feel like that often or for long periods of times, after sleepin 2 hours, the nausea is about a 2/10, was 5-6 earlier. and I feel a touch better....  Ellen DOB: 9/7/1965 Dx 6/6/2011, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER+, HER2- Chemotherapy 6/29/2011 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Ellence (epirubicin), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxol (paclitaxel), Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 1/5/2012 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Hormonal Therapy 1/17/2012 Surgery 1/31/2012 Prophylactic ovary removal Radiation Therapy 3/10/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2011 06:13PM rabbit wrote: She called the office and the receptionist was very unsympathetic. They told her they did not have any opening before her Aug 31st appt.  She is having a deja vu....9 years ago when dx she was told that this spot she saw herself on the mammo was nothing, and 2 years later during her breast exam at the dr. office, her dr. felt it. So hers was there for 2 years that she knows of and they didn't seem concerned. She now sees something eerily similar to that in the same breast but a different area (she had a lumpectomy) and they are brushing her off... I told her to insist on speaking to the onco's nurse or the onco asap.
Posts.Title: A little advice or encouragement for a friend rabbit rabbit

Posts.Content: rabbit wrote: Went with my friend today who is a 9 year BC survivor, for her yearly mammo. She said she was concerned about the films she saw, that there were 2 spots that were bright white, small a few inches apart from each other, and then a hazy, cloudy area closer to the nipple. She said it looks a bit like it did when she was first diagnosed 9 years ago....I told her it could be scarring from her lumpectomy or calcifications....I know she's worried and I told her I would ask about it on the forum here. Her next onco appt is not until end of August, she's going to call the dr. tomorrow and ask for it to be sooner, but if anyone has had this happen before and can "calm" her a bit, please let me know :)   Ellen DOB: 9/7/1965 Dx 6/6/2011, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER+, HER2- Chemotherapy 6/29/2011 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Ellence (epirubicin), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxol (paclitaxel), Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 1/5/2012 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Hormonal Therapy 1/17/2012 Surgery 1/31/2012 Prophylactic ovary removal Radiation Therapy 3/10/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Remove the rest of the lymph nodes or rely on rads? rabbit Artemis

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2012 08:09PM rabbit wrote: hi Artemis thanks so much for your story, very similar to me for sure. I am much more comfortable with the rads option after seeing my MO today :) he reassured me that my survival rate in 5 yrs is about 95% either way. Now I find out I have to get my ovaries taken out and if I want, a total hysterectomy....I remember this being mentioned early on in my dx but forgot about it :(   so now, ovaries or the total? My MO said the ovaries were important, not the uterus so much..another dilema! LOL
Posts.Title: Remove the rest of the lymph nodes or rely on rads? rabbit Artemis

Posts.Content: rabbit wrote: I am in a big dilemma, I had a lumpectomy on the 5th of Jan. they took 2 nodes, first one showed a 2.5mm tumor the second was negative. I saw my BS today and she said that normally with the macrometastasis in the lymph nodes, and doing neoadjuvant therapy, they would go back and remove the rest of the nodes. After talking to her for a bit, she said she wanted to call my RO and get her opinion and when she came back in the room, she said my RO was very confident if there was anything else in my lymph nodes, that she would get it with rads. My BS said that there was approximately a 15% chance there was more cancer in my nodes, that it can skip a node, so the positive node didn't mean there was no more cancer. Now, I see my MO Wed. and then meet with my RO the following Monday, the 23rd of Jan. I am so confused. Do I trust the 3 doctors with my life and hope the rads will get it all, or do I go back into surgery, knowing I am a HUGE risk for major lymphedema, and remove all those right axillary nodes?   I was told a PET scan will not show any growth less than 1cm and we know since I did chemo first, if there's anything there, it's well under 1cm. Is there any scan that will show lymph node involvement that maybe only 1mm or 2mm? I have so many questions, do I get a 2nd opinion from another MO or RO?  I feel like I just did almost 6 months of chemo, surgery etc. and now have a huge hurdle to jump. I either trust the docs and go with rads and pray it kills anything that may be there...or I go aggressive, remove all those nodes and possibly for no reason. There must be a way to see if there is in fact any involvement, even if it's micro... Help :(   Ellen DOB: 9/7/1965 Dx 6/6/2011, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER+, HER2- Chemotherapy 6/29/2011 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Ellence (epirubicin), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxol (paclitaxel), Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 1/5/2012 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Hormonal Therapy 1/17/2012 Surgery 1/31/2012 Prophylactic ovary removal Radiation Therapy 3/10/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Remove the rest of the lymph nodes or rely on rads? rabbit Artemis

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2012 09:23PM rabbit wrote: thank you all so much for your responses, I need all the input I can get, it's a major decision.  SpecialK, the reason they know I am at HUGE risk for lymphedema is because I had a blood clot in my external jugular and got lymphedema from that...and just taking out the 2 nodes, I have a pocket of fluid under my arm, I have a little water retention in my feet off and on for years as well. I am just the perfect candidate for it. I think after seeing my MO Wed. and my RO the 23rd, I will then see another MO and get a 2nd opinion...a doctor that has nothing to do with my "group of oncologists". If that one agrees rads are the way to go, I may go with it. I still don't understand how there is no test to find if other nodes are involved without operating. thanks again all. I would be curious to see if anyone knows statistics of more nodes being involved if the sentinel node was positive and the 2nd node negative.  Hugs to all!
Posts.Title: Remove the rest of the lymph nodes or rely on rads? rabbit Artemis

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 08:57PM rabbit wrote: hi everyone,  I can tell you that they did chemo first with me because the MRI showed my tumor was over 4cm, and 2 lymph nodes were slightly inflammed. They weren't sure it was mets, because I had my biopsy done a week or so before and the lymph nodes could of just been inflammed from that.  I am guessing the grade 3 had something to do with it too but the size was the main thing. They wanted to shrink it and stop anything in it's path before surgery so I could hopefully get away with a lumpectomy, which I did. I have pretty much decided on rads....but not 100%, will make my final decision on Monday when I see the RO. I want to thank everyone for their input here, this forum has been unbelievable for me. Hugs to everyone!
Posts.Title: Remove the rest of the lymph nodes or rely on rads? rabbit Artemis

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2012 08:06PM rabbit wrote: you all are giving me such great info to ponder on, thanks so much!! I am reading, and reading and reading your links, articles etc.  reesie, I will keep that in mind, I forgot that the rads could cause some lymphedema, I will find out more when I speak to my RO. I see the MO tomorrow and am so anxious to pick his brain about this! The articles and studies you all of given me info on are making me want to stick with my first instinct, to let rads get anything that may be there. I do fall in that "under 5cm" category so I'm feeling more confident with this. I will let you all know what I decide, what the MO tells me and so forth. Please keep the info coming and anyone else that reads this and has a similar experience, please share!! hugs to all!

Posts.Content: rabbit wrote: I am a bit freaked, I just had the lumpectomy, port removal and SNB on the 5th of Jan. and the preadmission testing consisted only of bloodwork.  Today I went for preadmission testing for my ovary/tube removal (I would call it an ooph but it's the tubes too...or does ooph include that?) and at the same hospital, different surgeon, I had to do blood work, urine test, EKG, chest xray, and on the blood work, the tech said "we are doing a blood typing in case you need a transfusion" I was like "WHAT?" She said that I need to wear a special bracelet during surgery in case they need to do a transfusion, that the Dr. ordered this. I am a bit stressed about this, if anything, I would of thought they would of been worried about blood loss during my last surgey as I was on lovenox for 5 months prior, but was taken off of it a few days before that surgery.  Anyone have a good explination for this? I hope so LOL  Ellen DOB: 9/7/1965 Dx 6/6/2011, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER+, HER2- Chemotherapy 6/29/2011 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Ellence (epirubicin), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxol (paclitaxel), Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 1/5/2012 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Hormonal Therapy 1/17/2012 Surgery 1/31/2012 Prophylactic ovary removal Radiation Therapy 3/10/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Log in to post a reply

At least I know I should start feeling better the next few days. I'm supposed to go to the casino with my mom tomorrow, we go once every 4-6 weeks planned either right before or right after tx for immune system purposes..I am praying some of the bone pain subsides by them so I can enjoy my fun time I have planned for this tx cycle.  I keep hearing something about taking antihistamines, is that for docetaxel? Is it worth a try or am I thinking of something else it helps? hugs to all!!

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2011 12:08PM rabbit wrote: hi Maria~ they thought my tumor was 1.2 cm from the mammogram and ultra sound, then after the MRI showed it was 4-5 cm...so that's when we decided to go with chemo first, hoping to shrink it enough to "POSSIBLY" get away with a lumpectomy.  My MRI showed 2 lymph nodes on the right side where the tumor is, slightly inflammed, so either the biopsy set them off a few days earlier or it's the BIG C starting up there...will know more after op as well :) I am not triple negative, ER+ and HER2-..but otherwise we have lots of similarites....wish you the best in everything! Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2011 06:57AM rabbit wrote: wow, day 5 and I am a mess. That docetaxel crap is killing me, it better be killing the cancer too.  The nausea came on during infusion but mild, wore a sancuso patch and got some ativan during infusion.  Was told ativan helps with nausea as well as relaxing you. Had to take a zofran towards the end of infusion. But came home feeling ok, just tired, took a nap for 2 hours, woke feeling pretty darn good.  The 2nd day was good most of the day, no nausea, no pain, but after dinner I got severe upper GI pain. This chemo is triggering all of my GERD and hiatal hernia problems, worse than ever. This has happened for 3 nights in a row now. I go through my max dose of 80mg of omeprazole, a handful of tums, half a bottle of maalox, all in a night.  The 3rd night, I went to bed with bone pain, nail beds tender as could be and they are getting worse. Because of the horrible upper GI problems I have not been able to swallow the LGlutamine powder, but have been able to do the VitB6 and Acetyl L Carnetine.  I am taking a 5mg oxycodone when I wake up and later in the day. Anyone have any suggestions for the nail bed pain or the bone pain? Will this fade anytime soon or am I stuck with this pain and problems daily for each tx? Thanks all!
Posts.Title: Docetaxel/Taxotere question rabbit Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 12:04AM rabbit wrote: Anyone get thrush on docetaxel? I just got a script for diflucan and more Mary's Magic Mouthwash even thought that doesn't seem to do the trick this time..I just noticed inflammation in between my index finger and thumb, and the bottoms of my feet...they are inflammed, and I hate to say it, but my behind is inflammed too, I thought it was from the diarrhea but now I'm thinking that I have inflammation or sores/fungus, throughout my body. I can feel the irritation down my esophagus, I'm thinking my body is detoxing big time, or flaring up..any ideas?

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2011 01:23AM rabbit wrote: cp418 I think it's important that you posted this, to make us and others aware of possible problems. There are some things that I feel would of never been looked at or monitored throughout life, without my pushing the Dr.  I know I had a thyroid disease almost a year before the Dr. agreed and put me on meds for it. I had all the symptoms and insisted on bloodwork done several times, my antibodies were high but nothing else was off so he wouldn't treat it and just said "one day  you will need medication for it" found out later that that's not necessarily true, it could of possibly been treated a bit earlier Anyways, I know this is much more serious but it's important listen to your body, make sure you are being monitored and voice your opinions about your body to your Dr. at all times, it's his/her job to make sure you are looked after, if you aren't happy with your Dr. get another one.
Posts.Title: Anyone develop cardiac issues post chemo? cp418 Pegs

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2011 09:58AM rabbit wrote: hi Debbie thanks so much for your info! Are you from Australia? I lived in the sw of Australia for 8 years...LOVE ginger beer and know a store here that sells it, very expensive but will go get some asap, anything to give me an excuse to have some of that LOL My first treatment was just over a month ago, my weight has gone up and down with this, but only give or take 3-4 pounds, I lose a few pounds easily and then put it on easily, I am probably almost to the pound where I was from the start date, I had just lost over 30 pounds (14 kilos or so) right before dx and have at least another 30 pounds to go so I'm really praying I don't put on anything or much. The bad thing is like you said, the flu like symptoms linger worse the 2nd time, I have only been able to walk a few times this go around and am worn out when I do. If I can get the energy to do more exercise I think I can keep the weight part under control, but if it gets harder, it will be worse again on FEC number 3. :( hugs to you and keep us posted, maybe join our July chemo group? We have a bunch of great ladies there...and I would love to follow your SEs and how you are going through your next batch of chemo!! xoxo
Posts.Title: Docetaxel/Taxotere question rabbit Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2011 10:29AM rabbit wrote: hi Debbie, thanks so much for sharing that info!! We have a very similar diagnosis, ER+ HER2-, Grade 3 IDC, my tumor was thought to be 1.2 cm at first with mammo and US but the MRI showed it over 4 cm. Don't know the stage yet, do know that 2 of my nodes looked "slightly inflammed" in the MRI. The only difference is that I am doing chemo first, then surgery Dec 16th, praying for a lumpectomy if it shrinks enough since we know my BRCA gene is negative.  I do eat 4-5 small meals a day and find it helps..I eat TONS of veggies and some fruit, just had grapefruit for breakfast, normally I eat plain organic yogurt with blueberries or some fruit, it helps keep the yeast infections away and the mouth sores seem to be to a minimum.  I have been using cornstarch powder for my underarms, I got a little rash under both arms, but have had that happen before chemo, I think it's cause our bodies are so out of whack. Where in Australia do you live? I lived in the SW for 8+ years, beautiful country!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2011 10:34PM rabbit wrote: Hi all, I went to the onco today to discuss changing the game plan or lowering the dose a bit. The SEs totally knocked me out for almost 2 weeks. I told him I seriously did not think I could go through this 3 more times. He suggested I go to weekly tx of taxol for 9 more weeks, since I had a potent dose of docetaxel he said that would make up for about 3 rounds of taxol (normally it would be 12 weeks).  He thinks I will have fewer SEs with this lower dose of taxol and said the success rate of killing the cancer, recurrance etc. was the same with this drug as it would of been with docetaxel. Anyone here know much about doing taxol weekly as opposed to docetaxel every 3 weeks? I may make another post about this but thought I would ask here first :)

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2011 09:00AM rabbit wrote: hi Natalie Thanks for explaining that,it helps us all to be more aware! I had a funeral on Monday (a friend in her mid 70s that my mom and I played bingo with for years) she was covered with cancer from head to toe....hospitalized with pneumonia at the end and died a week later. So it's scary, the pneumonia thing! So glad you knocked it. I really try to avoid the crowns from like a few days after chemo til maybe day 15 or 16. The only time I go out much at all is that last 5-6 days before my next chemo. But I had to go on cipro last time too...so you never know. I ask everyone before they come visit "have you had a cold or been sick, been around anyone that has?" Cause if so,no go! What is ANC? I can't recall that abbreviation.... mrsnjband, thanks so much for you post too...I know everyone is different. Kymn on the boards here also had a rough and totally different SE time with it than the FEC so I guess I have to wait and see. I sure hope I sail through it too! LOL hugs to all :)

Posts.Content: rabbit wrote: Hi everyone, I am new here :) I had a suspicous mammogram a few weeks ago, last week had a spot compression and an ultra sound, the radiologist said she was pretty sure it was malignant, it's a 1cm mass and there are tiny calcifications in the same area that she said looked like "satellites". I had a biopsy Wed. My Dr. already set up an appt with a surgeon on Monday at 4:30 where I will get the results. I am extremely nervous but preparing myself, I am a fighter and I am very optimistic, I also do a lot of natural therapies and have already started a liquid mixture called Mell-MH which is supposed to help starve many types of breast cancers. I've also started building my immune system doing Vit D, B, C, selenium...  I know 1cm is very small, and I think the radiologist said it was in the ducts...if there is tiny calcifications (possibly more spots of cancer) next to the growth, does that mean it's probably spread to the lymph nodes, any help and thoughts of what to expect would be greatly appreciated. Thanks!  Ellen DOB: 9/7/1965 Dx 6/6/2011, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER+, HER2- Chemotherapy 6/29/2011 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Ellence (epirubicin), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxol (paclitaxel), Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 1/5/2012 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Hormonal Therapy 1/17/2012 Surgery 1/31/2012 Prophylactic ovary removal Radiation Therapy 3/10/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Log in to post a reply

Hoping to see a plastic surgeon before leaving if they can get me in. I will probably need a mastectomy on the right breast and need to decide if I want to get the left removed as well for preventative measures.  I am okay...shocked a bit,  it's a lot to take in. Posts.Title: Docetaxel/Taxotere question rabbit Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: rabbit wrote: Did FEC for 4 rounds, started Docetaxel Sept 21st, 3 more rounds to go every 3 weeks. On day 2 or 3 of the Docetaxel, I did a detox bath of epsom salts, hydrogen peroxide and baking soda and used a loofa brush to do a lymphatic drainage. The bone pain and aches felt better later that day but I think it was that night or later that morning I noticed my feet were red, inflamed and just tender to walk on.  Then within 24 hours of that I noticed the soft tissue in between my index and thumb was the same, red, swollen looking and tender to touch. I looked it up on the internet, posted on here in a few places and it appeared to be hand-foot syndrome. I saw my onco on day 8, he and the PA decided it was not hand-foot syndrome that it was more a direct reaction to the Docetaxel, he said he sees this exact reaction in another chemo but it was the first he had seen it with Docetaxel.  He said to keep it moisturized and that it could possibly flare up through the rest of the treatments, but it should go away once I'm done with chemo end of Nov. I was told that my hands were more splotchy like the hand-foot syndrome but my feet were too covered with redness, it was not like the hand-foot syndrome symptoms.  A few days later, my hands got much worse, the redness and some patches actually spread around the sides and to the edges and tops of each hand and a few patches on top of my thumbs and a few fingers. I called the onco and was told to stop taking the B6, L-Glutamine and Acetyl L Carnetine (the supplements that I had started day of the new chemo to help prevent neuropathy) that it was possible it was a reaction to that.... I bought some bag balm (udder butter) and for the last 2 days have been coating my hands and feet in it, putting on socks and gloves to keep the moisture in at night and a few times during the day. I have been doing hydrocortisone cream in between these treatments. Today my hands are a touch better, my feet for a few days have slowly been getting better. I was just curious if anyone else has gone through this, or similar. I don't think I can do this for 3 more treatments, I am achy and moody, the bone pain was insane for 4-5 days and not being able to walk for days..it's a real PIA!  Hopefully someone has been through this and can help me out! I don't know if it's the supplements, hand-foot syndrome, or just simply a reaction to the Docetaxel.... thanks in advance and hugs!!  Ellen DOB: 9/7/1965 Dx 6/6/2011, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER+, HER2- Chemotherapy 6/29/2011 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Ellence (epirubicin), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxol (paclitaxel), Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 1/5/2012 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Hormonal Therapy 1/17/2012 Surgery 1/31/2012 Prophylactic ovary removal Radiation Therapy 3/10/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Hand-Foot Syndrome or similar SE? rabbit rabbit

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2011 01:40PM rabbit wrote: hi Jmull My hands and feet, especially feet are still peeling in huge amounts, 6 weeks later , it was the docetaxel that did it to me, I have had 4 weekly taxols now (which they switched me to after the reaction)  and it never retriggered it, it's just still peeling, so for me the taxol is good, so weird how we all react differently, the taxol is so much nicer to me, I'm so glad they agreed to do this one. good luck to you, I put udder butter on my feet and hands at night and work socks and gloves, it really helped heal them much faster.

Posts.Content: rabbit wrote: I'm not sure how to title this, but I was told there are some CDs you can listen to while getting chemo that actually help you relax and take in the chemo, almost like a visualization technique that possibly helps make the chemo work better, safer....if anyone has tried this and thinks it works, please give me a link or place to check them out. I am VERY interested.  I googled it and found this  http://www.relaxintohealing.com/index.php?pr=Chemotherapy_Healing_Guided_Imagery_Affirmation_Meditation but not sure if this is what I am looking for and wanted to speak to someone that actually has tried it...my sister was told about it by a massage therapist when we were in NY a month ago and she forgot to get the details of it before we left, so trying to track it down now.... Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 03:00AM rabbit wrote: cool breeze thanks so much for your reply, I know that the liquid herb has whole grain alcohol in it but what I read about alcohol, I was thinking drinking too much alcohol, which I am a very ocassional social drinker. I will ask the surgeon tomorrow and/or the oncologist I end up seeing. It is worth looking into more for sure, and you are right, I am sure it's not a cure all, but it may help slow it down or stop it from spreading, I use natural remedies for some things and have avoided antibiotics several times, and heard some incredible stories, but I do believe there is a time and a place for everything and obviously something as serious as this, I will be doing what the dr. says and possibly combine it with some natural steps, with the dr. approving of course :) Also,  because the radiologist said she was concerned that these tiny calcifications are in the same area as the mass, and she referred to it as possible "satellites" of the cancer. I hope you are right and it's just calcifications or DCIS.   hi Sara1970, the mixture is made by goodherbs, which I use several of their products, it's a combination of asian violet, asian dandelion, dulse, inkberry, japanese honeysuckle, prickley ash, sheep sorrel and based with 27% whole grain alcohol. It's a liquid I take 30 drops 3 x a day. I am going to keep reading the forum, I too have read tons of info, googled everything possible. Looked at my mammogram and ultrasound a dozen times..  My sisters, mother, father and best friend are all going with me to the appt. But I think I will just have my mom go in the room with me at first. I'll post once I know more.
